content:
If the message folders are on your PC, you can move them in one of two ways:

  1. exit thunderbird, locate the profile folder, copy the desired message folders (probably in Mail\Local Folders folder) to external media. Ignore the msf file. On the Mac, follow same process of exiting thunderbird and copying the message folder to the Mail\Local Folders folder on the Mac.
  2. option two is to install the importexporttools addon on both. then, highlight each folder, rightclick, select importexporttools option to export mbox file. Then, on the Mac, highlight Local Folders, rightclick, and select the importexportools option to import mbox. repeat as needed.

However, if you want them all in same folder, use the importexporttools option to export eml and on the Mac,highlight the desired folder, and use the importexporttools option to import eml

Hi David,

Thank you for your response. But your instructions were too general for me to follow with confidence.

It seems that this should be simpler than it is. But I also am not technical. My goal is to merge the two folders from Thunderbird on my PC to Thunderbird on my mac book. And I'd like them all to be accessible within Thunderbird along with the already existing emails on my mac book. I'm not sure if this means the "same folder" as you mentioned.

Is there a way to move the two folders from TB PC to TB Mac manually and have the two moved folders accessible within my already existing mac book TB email?

What folder on mac book should they be moved to in order to access all within mac book TB? And I also would like move my address book/contacts. But that is secondary, unless it can be done at the same time.

Regarding the import/export tool. I did attempt this. The export is easy. It's the import that concerns me. I want to move both the folders. But it didn't seem to allow me to choose those two main folders. It showed all the items in within those folders and there are many. And having never used the import/export tool, I don't want to guess and then overwrite existing emails.

I'm now at a loss of how to move forward. There seems to be so many options I've become more confused. But it seems my goal is very simple. Merge my personal emails from my work PC Thunderbird to my personal Mac book Thunderbird without overwriting the emails already on my Mac book.

I've resigned from my job ironically at a major tech company that I have been at just short of 25 years. I can't bear to loose years of personal emails, many from my parents who both passed away in 2024 with pictures, voicemails, just so many memories.

Are there any visual instructions I can view? Or videos with the steps to follow?

Thanks!!!
creator: lisabauer

content:
Twelve years ago I migrated a friend's Thunderbird profile from a Windows laptop to a MacBook Pro. The migration was very simple and today she still uses the same profile on a new MacBook Pro. I copied the "Thunderbird" folder from ... \AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\ on the laptop to the MacBook Pro and pasted it in ~/Library/here before launching Thunderbird. Everything was there.

My suggestion: copy the profile folder xxxxxxxx.default-release (or similar name) from the PC to the MacBook where - Thunderbird closed - you paste it in ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/... In the Thunderbird folder on the Mac look up the profiles.ini file and open it with Text-Edit.app. In the paragraph

[General] StartWithLastProfile=1 Version=2

replace the 1 with a 0 (zero) Now when you start TB it will first open the Thunderbird profile manager and propose a list of profiles in which you select the profile you want to start with (image). So you could choose your old migrated PC profile to start with Thunderbird ...

content:
Magpie, I am very sorry but my instructions from yesterday had a big flaw. After pasting your old profile folder from the PC in the "Profiles" folder of your Thunderbird installation on the MacBook and starting the profile manager Thunderbird could not recognise the old profile since it was still unknown to the profiles.ini file.

I should have written • start TB which will open the profile manager • in the profile manager click on "Create Profile..." which will open a "Create Profile Wizard" • click on "Continue", give a name to the new profile and then click on the "Choose Folder...." button (image) • this will open a Finder navigation window in which you must navigate to your PC profile folder in "Profiles", select the PC profile folder, click "Open" which will bring back the "Create Profile Wizard" • click "Done" which returns to the profile manager window where eventually you click "Start Thunderbird" to open your old profile from the PC
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Located this regarding the error: https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/blog/exchange/updated-requirements-for-smtp-relay-through-exchange-online/3851357/replies/3974577 It specifically mentions this: "451 4.4.4 Mail received as unauthenticated, incoming to a recipient domain configured in a hosted tenant which has no mail-enabled subscriptions. ATTR5."

In Thunderbird open the Error Console

  • Tools > Developer Tools > Error Console

You could clear the Error Console, then close it Restart Thunderbird and wait for all incoming to get checked. Then try to send Open Error Console Post an image showing the contents.

Do you see something like this:

  • mailnews.smtp: Command failed: 535 Authentication unsuccessful, SmtpClientAuthentication is disabled for the Tenant. Visit https://aka.ms/smtp_auth_disabled for more information.

If yes then the issue in using SMTP maybe because SMTP has not been switched on/enabled. This is not due to Thunderbird.

The link mentioned in error console : https://aka.ms/smtp_auth_disabled That link goes to this location - I specifically include the info on 'enable smtp':

  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/clients-and-mobile-in-exchange-online/authenticated-client-smtp-submission#enable-smtp-auth-for-specific-mailboxes

However, it would be useful to see what the Error Console is displaying.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Please note: in a Microsoft Account, all mail account/email address are regarded as 'alias' accounts.

It means you can only 'send' via smtp using whatever email address is set up as 'primary'. You can choose what is set up as primary, but it must be done via the webmail Microsoft Account accesed via a browser.

Please note: Passwords for 'alias' accounts now need to be the same as the Microsoft Account password.

In Thunderbird 'Authentication Method' for incoming and outgoing smtp must use 'Oauth2'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Is this an imap mail account ? If yes - try subscribing to see it.

  • In Folder Pane, right click on the mail account name folder and selct 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'Refresh'
  • Select the 'Sent' folder or whatever the server calls it eg: 'Sent Mail'
  • Click on 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'

Then make sure the Account Settings are using it.

  • Account Settings > Copies & Folders
  • Select 'Place a copy in'
  • Select 'Other' and choose the name of Sent folder on the account.

Check you are synchronised to download full copies of emails.

  • Click on 'Synschronisation & Storage'
  • Select 'Keep messages in all folders for this account on this computer'
  • Click on 'Advanced' button
  • Make sure the Sent folder is selected in the list and click on 'OK'
  • Select 'Synchronise all messages localy regardless of age'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you read my instructions you would notice I said this: Is this an imap mail account ? If yes - try subscribing to see it. followed by instructions on what to do for an imap account.

You have stated "It's a POP account. "

That means it's not an imap account, so therefore you cannot subscribe to see any folders on the server. So in Account Settings, do not not use the settings I stated for an IMAP account.

Pop accounts just have permission to access the server Inbox and download whatever has not been previously downloaded. Pop accounts do not synchronise with any folder on the server. They are completely independent copy of folders and emails on your computer.

Yahoo by default will store any email you send via smtp in the webmail account folder used for sent mail. Gmail does the same and they do it via default just in case Pop users want to use their webmail account or change to an imap account. So the fact you can see those saved sent emails on the server is not relevant in your case - but is useful.

RE: POP account I need to know how this pop account is set up.

Did you set up the pop account as a deferred account which uses the 'Local Folders' account as a global Inbox? In this case you sould not see that name of the pop account in the Folder Pane nor does it have it's own set of folders because it's using 'Local Folders'.

How to check to see if POP is set up as normal or using a Global Inbox:

  • In Account Settings
  • Select 'Server Settings' for the pop account
  • Look bottom right and click on 'Advanced..' button
  • What is selected ?

If 'inbox for this account' - then you have a normal pop account. You will see your pop account in the Fodler Pane and it will use it's own set of folders.

IF 'Inbox for different account' and you chose 'Global Inbox (Local Folders)' - it's a deferred account. In which case you should not a pop account listed in Fodler PAne - you should only see 'Local Folders' and it gets all incoming pop mail into the Local Folders Inbox.

Tell me what you have got selected. Confirm you also have this setting selected : View > Folders > All
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Hello, Carolyne, here's what to do.

  1. click the hamburger' menu (three short stacked lines) in upper right
  2. click 'new account' and then click email
  3. on next screen, enter your name and your email address. NOTHING MORE.
  4. press enter key and thunderbird will set up the account. Press DONE
  5. next, a screen will popup from Yahoo, asking for your password. enter that and press enter key
  6. yahoo will now ask to do extra validation. The screen will look like the attached screenshot with the words "Is it really you?"
  7. one of the options is a phone call. click that and you will receive a call on your landline phone with a code. I suggest having pencil and paper ready so you can write it down as codes may be stated quickly
  8. then type in the code and you're done. :)

The email will be at yahoo, not thunderbird. Let me know if you need more assistance.
creator: davidsk

content: UPDATE: If the account is already set up, you may just need to proceed from step 5 in my earlier note.
creator: davidsk
